case_data.name: Jones v. Murphy
case_data.plaintiff_description: Persons subjected to strip searches at the Baltimore Central Booking.  2 Subclasses: those detained for more than 48 hours without having seeing a commissioner, and 2) those arrested for minor, nondrug, nonviolent offenses

related_cases.name: Maryland NAACP v. Baltimore City Police Department

case_data.summary:
On May 12, 2005, male arrestees at the Baltimore Central Booking and Intake Center filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland. The plaintiffs sued the warden of Central Booking, the Baltimore Police Department, the City of Baltimore, and other state officials under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, asked the Court for injunctive relief, compensatory and consequential damages, and attorneys fees and costs. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants had violated their Fourth and Fourteenth Amendment rights when they engaged in unconstitutional strip searches of the plaintiffs and detained the plaintiffs for unreasonable lengths of time. This case was one of three cases alleging mistreatment of persons arrested and taken to Central Booking for booking and processing. The other cases were Maryland NAACP v. Baltimore City Police Department, 1:06-cv-01863-CCB (D. Md. 2006) and Rodney v. Murphy, 24-C-05004405, filed in Maryland state court.

Plaintiffs sought certification for five classes. First, the suspicionless strip search class which consisted of those who had been or would be arrested for crimes not involving weapons, drugs, or felony violence, who were strip searched by Central Booking employees without any individualized finding that they were harboring weapons, drugs, or other contraband. Second, the non-private strip search class was composed of those who had been or would be subjected to strip searches at Central Booking with other arrestees present. Third, the equal protection strip search class consisted of male arrestees strip searched at Central Booking while similarly-situated female arrestees were not. Fourth, the underwear strip search class was made up of male arrestees subjected to an underwear strip search while similarly-situated female arrestees were not. Fifth, the over-detention class consisted of those arrested without warrants who had been or would be detained for an unreasonable length of time (more than 48 hours) before presentment to a judicial officer for a determination of probable cause.

The defendants moved to dismiss the third amended complaint for failure to state a claim. The District Court (District Judge Catherine C. Blake) granted the motion in part and dismissed all claims against the City and the Police Department, rejecting the theory of "entrustment liability." Claims against the state defendants survived, with the exception of individual claims against the current warden. 470 F.Supp.2d 537 (D. Md. Jan 04, 2007).

On July 11, 2008, the district court (Judge Blake) issued a memorandum on the issue of whether the gender-differentiated search policy violated the Equal Protection Clause. The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment on the issue and denied the defendants' motion.

On March 19, 2009, the district court partially granted the plaintiffs' motion to certify a class. Specifically, the court certified the following subclasses: 1) those people detained for more than 48 hours without having been brought before a commissioner, and 2) those people arrested for minor, nondrug, nonviolent offenses and strip-searched before they were brought before a commissioner. The court declined to certify the following subclasses: 1) those people who weren't strip-searched privately, and 2) male arrestees who were searched to their underwear when female detainees were not.

For the next two years, discovery motions were exchanged, until the defendants filed a motion for partial summary judgment on January 14, 2011.

On March 5th, 2013 Judge Blake issued a memorandum and an order granting the motion for partial summary judgment. The court granted the motion under the doctrine of qualified immunity.

The plaintiffs filed an appeal on August of 2013. A panel of three judges rendered a decision on November 11, 2014. 771 F.3d 209 (4th Cir. 2014). The Circuit Court (Circuit Judge James Harvie Wilkinson III) affirmed the district court's decision to grant partial summary judgment for the defendants. The court noted that several police officers and guards testified that they found illegal contraband from these searches. And the searchers were being conducted in a private room. On the issue of qualified immunity, the court noted that the right to not be subjected to a strip search was not clearly established at the time of the searches. A Supreme Court decision was filed in 2012, settling aspects of the issue after the fact, but before this, officers who were conducting searches, could not reasonably tell if the searches were violating a constitutional right. The court found the defense of qualified immunity acceptable here, and determined that the motion for partial summary judgment was properly granted.

Circuit Judge James Andrew Wynn Jr. filed a concurring opinion in which he pointed out that the Supreme Court intimated in the Florence decision that there may be exceptions to the rule. That detainees not being admitted into the general population should not have to be stripped searched. The complexities of the exceptions had not been explored by the courts, and Judge Wynn noted that there needed to be more elaboration on this topic, so public officials would know how to act accordingly. However, the merits of the case were not be reached because of the granting of summary judgment.

On February 24, 2015 Judge Blake filed a memo regarding the January 31, 2011 motion for partial summary judgment. 2015 WL 790334. The motion was made by the warden-defendant, over the class of Plaintiffs claiming that Central Booking practiced "over-detention." The court held that the plaintiffs' theory of supervisor liability was defective because there was no evidence that the warden-defendant was deliberately indifferent to the constitutional injury of the Plaintiffs. The warden-defendant did not deny that there were detainees held longer than 48 hours, which was past what was constitutionally acceptable, but she argued that it was caused by factors outside of her control. The court agreed that the delays in presenting detainees before a court commissioner was the fault of the Baltimore police, the state's attorneys office, and court officials. Furthermore, the court argued that the warden had made several efforts to remedy the problem, and that the plaintiffs' complaint that it was not fast enough or proactive enough did not prove deliberate indifference. Finally, the court also granted the summary judgment motion on the theory of qualified immunity, so the defendant had no fair warning that her conduct was unconstitutional.

A few months later on June 15, 2015 the Court entered final judgment and closed the case.
case_data.summary_short: This class action lawsuit was filed on May 12, 2005 by two male arrestees in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland.  The plaintiffs alleged that they and all male arrestees taken to Central Booking were subjected to unconstitutional strip searches and many were subjected to "over detentions" in violation of the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C. § 1983.

and Intake Center

SUSAN MURPHY

Baltimore, Maryland  21202 
Individually and in his Official 
Capacity 
 
MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL OF 
BALTIMORE 
100 North Holliday Street 
Baltimore, Maryland 2120 
 
  and 
 
BALTIMORE CITY POLICE 
DEPARTMENT  
601 East Fayette Street 
Baltimore, MD 21202 
 
      Defendants 
 
CLASS ACTION 
 
SECOND AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR MONEY DAMAGES, INJUNCTIVE 
RELIEF, AND PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION, WITH JURY DEMAND 
 
Introduction 
1.  Plaintiffs Eric Jones, Dana West, and Gary Saunders bring this class 
action lawsuit on behalf of themselves and all other arrestees who (1) were 
subjected to strip searches while being held in the Baltimore Central Booking 
and Intake Center (“Central Booking”), waiting for presentment before a 
commissioner or other judicial officer on (a) misdemeanors not involving a 
weapon or drugs, or (b) non-violent, non-drug related felony charge(s); or (2) 
were subjected to strip, visual body cavity and/or squat searches not 
conducted in private; or (3) were males subjected to blanket strip, visual body 
  2

cavity and/or squat searches while being held in Central Booking, waiting for 
presentment before a judge or other judicial officer of the City of Baltimore 
regardless of the charges against them because similarly situated women were 
not subjected to such searches.   
2.  Plaintiffs Tonia Bowie, David Colyns, and Gary Saunders also bring this 
class action on behalf of themselves and all other persons who were arrested in 
the City of Baltimore but were not brought before a commissioner or other 
judicial officer for a probable cause hearing within 48 hours of their arrests.  
3.  Plaintiff Eric Jones brings an individual claim for his detention after his 
arrest without being brought before a commissioner or other judicial officer for 
a probable cause hearing within a reasonable time period.  
Classes 
4.  Plaintiffs move the Court to declare four separate classes, as described 
below. As used herein, “presentment” refers to the initial proceeding before the 
Court referred to in Maryland Rule 4-212(f).  The time period for all classes is 
from May 12, 2002 through final judgment in this case. 
5.  Plaintiffs Dana West, Eric Jones, and Gary Saunders and the class of 
persons they seek to represent (the “Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Class”) 
are arrestees arrested on (a) misdemeanors not involving a weapon or drugs, or 
(b) non-violent, non-drug related felony charge(s) who were subjected to strip 
searches without any individualized finding of reasonable suspicion that they 
  3

were concealing drugs, weapons or other contraband, by employees of Central 
Booking, while they were held in Central Booking waiting for presentment 
before a commissioner or other judicial officer.  
6.  The “Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Class Members” are not (prior 
to presentment) commingled with persons who have been ordered detained at 
Central Booking or the Baltimore City Detention Center (either because they 
could not post a bond or are held without bond). 
7.  The Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Class Members base their claims 
on the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution, which prohibits 
subjecting persons arrested on crimes not involving weapons or drugs to strip 
searches without an individualized finding of reasonable suspicion or probable 
cause that the person was concealing drugs, weapons or other contraband. 
8.  Plaintiffs Dana West, Eric Jones, and Gary Saunders also seek to 
represent a class of arrestees (the “Non-Private Strip Search Class”) who were 
subjected to strip, visual body cavity and/or squat searches by employees of 
Central Booking in the presence of other arrested persons while they were held 
in Central Booking waiting for presentment before a commissioner or other 
judicial officer. 
9.  The Non-Private Strip Search Class Members base their claims on the 
Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution, which prohibits 
subjecting persons to strip searches in a non-private setting. The Non-Private 
Strip Search Class includes all persons who were strip-searched regardless of 
  4

the offense on which they were arrested because it is the manner of the search, 
rather than the lack of reasonable suspicion, that makes the search 
unreasonable under the Fourth Amendment. 
10.  Plaintiffs Dana West, Eric Jones, and Gary Saunders additionally seek to 
represent a class (the “Equal Protection Strip Search Class”) of persons who are 
male arrestees arrested on all types of charges, including drug and violent 
offenses, who were subjected to strip, visual body cavity and/or squat 
searches, by employees of Central Booking, while they were held in Central 
Booking waiting for presentment before a commissioner or other judicial officer.  
Defendants subject male arrestees to such searches, but do not subject 
similarly situated female arrestees, including women charged with drug and 
violent offenses, to the searches.  
11.  The Equal Protection Strip Search Class Members base their claims on 
the equal protection component of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United 
States Constitution, which prohibits treating similarly situated men and 
women differently based on their gender. The Equal Protection Strip Search 
Class includes all men who were strip-searched, regardless of the offense on 
which they were arrested, because it is the application of the search to men but 
not women, rather than the lack of reasonable suspicion, that makes the 
search unreasonable under the Fourteenth Amendment.  
12.  Plaintiffs Tonia Bowie, David Colyns, and Gary Saunders also seek to 
represent a class (the “Overdetention Class”) of persons who were arrested in 
  5

the City of Baltimore and held at Central Booking for an unreasonable length of 
time (more than 48 hours) after their arrests without presentment.  
13.  The Overdetention Class Members base their claims on the Fourth 
Amendment of the United States Constitution, which requires a prompt 
presentment such as the one afforded by Maryland Rule 4-212(f), and creates a 
presumption of unreasonability and unconstitutionality if the pre-presentment 
detention exceeds 48 hours.   
14.  Furthermore, Maryland Rule 4-212(f) requires the presentment be done 
“without unnecessary delay and in no event later than 24 hours.”  The 
Maryland Court of Appeals has held that this Rule implements fundamental 
federal and state constitutional rights.  Logan v. State, 289 Md. 460, 425 A.2d 
632 (1981). 
15.  This action is brought, individually and on behalf of the Classes, against 
Mitchell Franks, Susan Murphy, and William Jednorski in their individual 
capacities, and against the Government of the City of Baltimore and the 
Baltimore City Police Department, pursuant to Section 1983 of the Civil Rights 
Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 1983, for damages and enforcement of their Fourth 
and Fourteenth Amendment Rights. 
16.  This action is brought by the Plaintiffs, individually and on behalf of the 
Classes, against Mitchell Franks in his official capacity as Warden of Central 
Booking, pursuant to Section 1983 of the Civil Rights Act of 1871, 42 U.S.C. § 
1983, and against the Government of the City of Baltimore and the Baltimore 
  6

City Police Department, for prospective injunctive relief to enforce their Fourth 
and Fourteenth Amendment Rights.

FACTUAL ALLEGATIONS 
Central Booking 
66.  The Baltimore Central Booking and Central Intake Center opened in 
1995 as the central location for booking and processing arrestees in Baltimore 
City.   
67.  Central Booking is an agency of the Division of Pretrial Detention and 
Services, which in turn is a division of the Maryland Department of Public 
Safety and Correctional Services. 
68.  The Division of Pretrial Detention and Services has jurisdiction over three 
agencies which handle the booking, processing, custody and control of 
Baltimore City arrestees:  
  a.  The Baltimore Central Booking and Intake Center; 
  b.  The Baltimore City Detention Center (“Detention Center”); and 
  c.  The Pretrial Release Service Program. 
69.  Approximately 100,000 arrestees are processed yearly in Central 
Booking.  
70.  Central Booking is not a detention center where persons are held 
pending trial or in a post conviction stage 
71.  Some persons detained and awaiting trial, while waiting for space at the 
  14

Detention Center, may remain at Central Booking temporarily and housed 
separately in different locations from pre-presentment arrestees.  
72.  The Baltimore City Detention Center is the pretrial detention facility for 
persons arrested in the City of Baltimore and detained while awaiting trial. 
73.   The Detention Center is in a separate building from Central Booking. 
74.  In the City of Baltimore, persons arrested in the City of Baltimore, 
including persons arrested by the Baltimore City Police Department and other 
police agencies under the authority and control of the City of Baltimore, are 
taken by the police to Central Booking for booking and processing.   
75.  Central Booking contains a central booking unit, a medical unit, a 
classification unit, records unit, court commissioner's offices, video bail 
facilities, and a computerized Arrest Booking System.  
76.  The Arrest Booking System provides fingerprint based identification of 
offenders utilizing Live Scan fingerprint technology, coupled with the State of 
Maryland’s Automated Fingerprint Identification System. 
77.  The Live Scan system employs technology that enables a positive 
identification of persons, that is, an identification based on the unique, 
biometric characteristic of fingerprints. 
78.  Many persons taken to Central Booking are arrestees who are brought in 
on very minor charges that could have been processed through citations (a 
citation is an order by a police officer to appear in court on a specified date 
  15

without an arrest).  
79.  Police officials have identified the use of citations as one way to reduce 
the number of minor offenders who end up at Central Booking.   
80.  However, the BPD and the City of Baltimore have failed to use citations 
in lieu of arrests due to a gross failure to properly train their officers in the 
proper methods for completing and issuing citations, and due to a desire and 
practice of summarily imprisoning persons for prior crimes believed to have 
been possibly committed. 
81.  The BPD and the City of Baltimore have further failed to use sufficient 
discretion in the decision of whether to arrest persons; have rewarded police 
officers for the quantity of arrests regardless of whether the arrests are based 
on probable cause, amounting to an arrest quota system; have encouraged and 
ratified overly aggressive and unconstitutional policing of streets and false 
arrests; and have failed to sufficiently train and encourage the prompt filing of 
arrest paperwork and entry of data into the arrest booking system. 
82.  Approximately one-third of the people whom city police arrest, and 
commit to Central Booking, not including those picked up on warrants, never 
even face charges, such as where prosecutors determine that there is not 
enough evidence to support a charge, or that the alleged wrongdoing, such as 
loitering, was abated by the arrest, and “decline” the case, that is, decline to 
prosecute the case. 
83.  The percentage of persons arrested by the BPD and the City of Baltimore, 
  16

committed to Central Booking, but not charged dwarfs the percentages in other 
Maryland jurisdictions, which have had “no charge” rates of less than one-half 
of 1 percent. 
84.  Persons arrested by BPD, committed to Central Booking, but not charged 
are so commonplace among Central Booking arrestees that they are referred to 
by Central Booking officials and others by a descriptive name:  “Walk 
Throughs.”  
85.  The BPD and the City have failed to use other options available in lieu of 
taking arrestees to Central Booking. 
86.  Persons arrested in warrantless arrests and committed to Central 
Booking are held at Central Booking following arrest until their presentment 
before a commissioner for a probable cause determination, pretrial release 
determination, and other reasons.  
87.  Persons who are ordered detained before trial, or who are ordered held 
pending posting of bond, are held in Central Booking before being “committed” 
to the “Towers,” that is, the Baltimore City Detention Center.   
88.  Persons ordered released at presentment are segregated from the 
“committed” persons in separate holding areas pending release.   
89.  Persons ordered committed at presentment are held separately from both 
persons awaiting presentment, and persons ordered released at presentment. 
90.  In 2000, Central Booking processed 66,541 male arrestees and 15,854 
  17

female arrestees.   
91.  Of the 82,395 people processed, 38,123 were released on their own 
recognizance.   
92.  Central Booking was designed to process up to 45,000 arrestees 
annually. 
93.  However, despite already exceeding Central Booking’s capacity in 2000, 
the BPD and the City of Baltimore, rather than look for ways to reduce the 
number of persons arrested or, once arrested, the number of arrested persons 
taken to Central Booking, escalated the number of arrests and took them all to 
Central Booking.   
94.  The number of persons arrested each year in the City by BPD and taken 
to Central Booking by BPD has steadily increased since 2000 and now exceeds 
100,000 persons per year. 
95.  The BPD and the City have throughout the class period continued to 
arrest and commit persons to Central Booking knowing that Central Booking 
has been operating in excess of full capacity throughout the class period. 
96.  Central Booking has no effective management system for booking and 
processing arrestees.  
97.  Central Booking does not maintain and update its computerized booking 
and inmate management systems and has allowed its booking and processing 
and inmate management systems to collapse. 
  18

98.  The Wardens have maintained a policy and practice of maintaining a 
presentment and detention policy at Central Booking that simply delays all 
presentments and detains arrestees until the system, in its sweet time, and 
with the resources it chooses, is ready to make presentments. 
99.  The fact that Central Booking has no effective booking or inmate 
management system has been documented by a series of reports and 
newspaper articles, as well as by court cases dating back many years.   
100.  At the extreme end, the fundamental dysfunction and mismanagement of 
Central Booking led to the May 2005 beating death by guards of a 52-year-old 
man detained on a $150.00 bond.   
101.  During the class period and before, Central Booking has had problems 
stopping the flow of contraband into Central Booking by Central Booking 
officers. 
102.  The City of Baltimore has described Central Booking as “dysfunctional” 
and lacking “appropriate or adequate management systems and practices to 
assure performance and accountability.”  COMPLAINT OF THE MAYOR AND CITY OF 
BALTIMORE, filed against Warden Susan Murphy, Rodney et al. v. Murphy, 
Circuit Court for Baltimore City, 24-C-05-004405, ¶¶ 8-9 (June 29, 2005). 
103.  The overcrowding and overdetentions are a longstanding, pervasive and 
continuing problem known to defendants during the class period. 
104.  The detention and release of arrestees in Central Booking is currently 
  19

governed partly by a temporary restraining order (the “Order”) issued in the 
case of Richard Rodney et al. v. Susan Murphy, Circuit Court for Baltimore 
City, case number 24-C-05004405.   
105.  The Order requires the warden of Central Booking to present each 
arrested person to a judicial officer no later than 24 hours after arrest, and to 
release any arrested person upon their being held for more than 24 hours 
without presentment, subject to the warden’s right to move the court for 
continued detention of such a person upon a showing of good cause.   
106.  The Order has been extended to February 9, 2006.  
107.  Upon information and belief, the Order has led to a reduction of the 
number of arrestees held more than 48 hours without presentment. 
108.  The Order did not enable Central Booking, the City, and the BPD to do 
anything they could have not done during and before the class period, had they 
desired to do so and cease violating the constitutional rights of arrestees. 
109.  The Order does not address the strip searching of arrested persons. 
The Warden’s Responsibilities For Arrestees 
At Central Booking 
 
95.  The Warden’s duties include training, supervising, monitoring and 
disciplining Booking Center staff. 
96.  The Warden’s duties also include formulating, implementing, and 
executing policies concerning the operation of Central Booking facilities.  
  20

97.  These duties include promulgating and implementing policies controlling 
the strip searches of arrestees, and promulgating and implementing policies 
ensuring the prompt presentment of arrestees, and the release of arrestees 
following their presentments.  
98.  The Warden has day-to-day training, supervisory, and disciplinary 
authority for all operations of Central Booking. 
99.  The Warden is also responsible for ensuring that each employee of 
Central Booking discharges his or her duties in accordance with the law and 
court orders. 
100.  For each arrested person brought to Central Booking, the Warden “holds 
the key to the cell” and has the power and ability to release arrestees arrested 
in warrantless arrests up and until a judicial officer issues a commitment order 
for an arrestee. 
101.  The Warden has the authority under the U.S. Constitution to release, or 
to order the release of, persons arrested in warrantless arrests if the arrestees 
have not had a probable cause hearing within 48 hours of arrest, absent 
exceptional circumstances. 
102.  At all times throughout the class period, the Warden has access to the

person was arrested; (b) the fact that the person is placed into the custody of 
  21

Central Booking; (c) the gender of the person; (d) the charges on which the 
person was arrested; (e) the date and time the person is brought into Central 
Booking; and (f) the fact that each and every person detained without 
presentment for more than 48 hours after arrest, or for an otherwise 
unreasonable length of time, is being so detained. 
103.  The Arrest Booking System maintained during the class period has had a 
queuing system that continuously tracks the amount of time each arrestee has 
been detained at Central Booking without presentment, and shows where the 
person is in the booking process.   
Central Booking Practice Of Strip Searching Arrestees 
104.  As used herein, “strip search” includes the removal, pulling down, or 
rearrangement of clothing for the visual inspection of an arrested person’s 
genital and/or anal areas, which may also include requiring the person to 
squat and cough, in the presence of guards and other inmates. 
105.  During the class period Central Booking has had and continues to have a 
written policy that allows male arrestees to be automatically searched to their 
underwear, and then strip searched for whatever reason, in any manner, and 
in the presence of other arrested males, if the searching officer for any reason 
suspects – reasonably or not -- that the arrested male is concealing 
contraband.  
106.   Meanwhile, Central Booking has had and continues to have a written 
  22

policy whereby similarly situated women are, instead of being searched to their 
underwear, patted down above their clothing, with no mention of a strip 
search. 
107.  Neither the written strip search policies nor the strip search practices in 
effect at Central Booking take account of an arrestee’s charge when deciding to 
strip search an arrestee. 
108.  Central Booking has and has had an informal practices of strip searching 
men in situations where similarly-situated women are not strip searched; of 
strip searching men arrested for crimes not commonly associated with the 
possession of weapons or drugs; and of strip searching persons in the presence 
of other arrested persons and staff not needed for that person’s search. 
109.  Staff at Central Booking subject virtually all men to strip searches before 
presentment without individualized reasonable suspicion based on the 
appearance or actions of arrestees, type of charge, or other criteria. 
110.  Staff at Central Booking subject virtually no women to strip searches 
before presentment. 
111.  As a result of these policies and practices, virtually every male arrestee 
processed at Central Booking, after being arrested and awaiting presentment 
on charges involving drugs, weapons, or violence, is strip searched without an 
individual determination of reasonable suspicion to justify the search, and 
regardless of the crime with which the person is charged. 
  23

112.  As a result of these policies and practices, virtually every male arrestee 
processed at Central Booking, after being arrested and awaiting presentment 
on charges involving drugs, weapons, or violence, is strip searched without a 
determination of reasonable suspicion to justify the search, and regardless of 
the crime with which the person is charged. 
113.  As a result of these policies and practices, a substantial percentage of 
male arrestees committed to Central Booking, after being arrested and awaiting 
presentment on charges not involving drugs, weapons, or violence, are 
subjected to a strip search conducted without an individual or other 
determination of any kind of reasonable suspicion to justify the search, and 
regardless of the crime with which the person is charged.  
114.  As a result of these policies and practices, virtually all persons strip 
searched at Central Booking after being arrested and awaiting presentment are 
strip searched in the presence of other persons.  
115.  The great majority of strip searches of the men ay Central Booking are 
not reasonably related to any legitimate security interest of Central Booking 
because the searches are not rationally related to any reason to believe the 
persons searched are concealing contraband in a place that would be revealed 
by the search.  
116.  Central Booking does not keep any logs or other records of any individual 
strip searches performed during the booking process. 
  24

117.  Each Warden had actual or constructive knowledge of the 
aforementioned strip search practices during his or her tenure, if not before. 
118.  Each Warden failed to take appropriate action(s) to ensure that arrestees 
are strip-searched upon individualized suspicion rather than based upon 
gender or due to blanket searches; or to ensure that arrestees are strip-
searched in a private setting. 
119.  Each Warden during the class period had actual or constructive 
knowledge that the staff of Central Booking were subjecting virtually all men 
but virtually no women to strip searches that were not reasonably related to a 
legitimate security interest of the institution, the Wardens were deliberately 
indifferent to the rights of male and female arrestees to be free from 
unconstitutional strip searches (or the Wardens tacitly authorized the 
searches), and there is a direct causal link between the inaction and failure to 
supervise of the Wardens and the injuries suffered by the men and women 
arrestees who were illegally strip searched. 
120.  The City of Baltimore, and the Baltimore City Police Department, through 
their agents, have had actual or constructive knowledge of the aforementioned 
practices since at least 2001.   
121.  Nonetheless, the City of Baltimore and the Baltimore City Police 
Department knowingly and as part of its policy, practice, and custom places its 
arrestees into the custody of Central Booking. 
  25

122.  The BPD and the City have an affirmative duty to protect arrestees from 
harm, including the risk of violations of constitutional rights by a third party to 
whom the arrestees are transferred. 
123.  The BPD and the City had a reasonable opportunity to prevent the harm 
to persons arrested by its police officers by not arresting and committing 
persons to Central Booking. 
124.     The BPD and the City had a reasonable opportunity to prevent the 
harm to persons arrested by its police officers by not arresting and committing 
persons to Central Booking where probable cause for the arrest did not exist. 
125.  The BPD and the City had a reasonable opportunity to prevent the harm 
to persons arrested by its police officers by not arresting and committing 
persons to Central Booking who, even though probable cause for the arrest 
existed, the BPD and the City knew would not be charged. 
126.  The BPD and the City had a reasonable opportunity to prevent the harm 
to persons arrested by its police officers but who could have been issued a 
citation in lieu of arrest, including those arrested simply so that Central 
Booking could obtain their identities. 
127.  The BPD and the City wholly failed to take any affirmative act reasonably 
calculated to protect arrested persons and prevent unconstitutional strip 
searches.

Central Booking Practice Of Detaining Arrestees Booked Into Central 
Booking 
128.  Central Booking, despite having presentments conducted on-site, has an 
informal practice of detaining thousands of arrestees arrested in warrantless 
arrests for more than 48 hours during the class period. 
129.  As a result of these informal practices, a substantial number of persons 
arrested and processed at Central Booking are detained for more than 48 
hours after their arrests without a presentment.   
130.  Central Booking has even detained a substantial number of persons 
more than 3 days before presenting them. 
131.  Central Booking has even detained a substantial number of persons 
more than 4 days before presenting them.  
132.  Central Booking keeps computerized logs showing the arrestees’ times of 
arrest, arrival at Central Booking, presentment, and release, among other 
events. 
133.   Each Warden had actual or constructive knowledge of the 
aforementioned practices during his or her tenure, if not before. 
134.  The Warden failed to take appropriate action(s) to reduce the demands 
on Central Booking or increase the capacity of Central Booking to process more 
arrestees, such that arrested persons brought to Central Booking could be 
processed in a timely manner. 
  27

135.  Each Warden has had same-time actual or constructive knowledge the 
moment each and every person was being detained without presentment 
beyond 48 hours after arrest, but failed to either release each such person at 
the expiration of 48 hours or ensure that each such person was presented to a 
commissioner or other judicial officer, and instead continued to detain each

136.  Each Warden during the class period had actual or constructive 
knowledge that the staff of Central Booking were not presenting arrestees 
before 48 hours, the Wardens were deliberately indifferent to the rights of male 
and female arrestees to be presented within 48 hours of arrest, or the Wardens 
tacitly authorized the overdetentions, and there is a direct causal link between 
the inaction and failure to supervise of the Wardens and the injuries suffered 
by the men and women arrestees who were not presented within 48 hours of 
arrest. 
137.  The City of Baltimore, and the Baltimore City Police Department, through 
their agents, have had actual or constructive knowledge of the aforementioned 
practices since at least 2001.   
138.  Nonetheless, the City of Baltimore and the Baltimore City Police 
Department knowingly and as part of their policy, practice, and custom places 
its arrestees into the custody of Central Booking. 
139.  The BPD and the City have an affirmative duty to protect arrestees from 
harm, including the risk of violations of constitutional rights by a third party to 
  28

whom the arrestees are transferred.   
140.  The BPD and the City had reasonable opportunity to prevent their 
arrestees from being held at Central Booking for 48 hours after arrest without 
presentment, such as by using those methods described herein above. 
141.  The BPD and the City wholly failed to take any affirmative act reasonably 
calculated to protect arrested persons and prevent unconstitutional detentions 
without presentment. 
142.  In August 2005 a study commissioned by the State of Maryland that 
analyzed the processing of persons committed to Central Booking and the 
processes of moving arrestees through Central Booking concluded that 24 
hours was all the time needed to process arrestees through Central Booking 
and present them to judicial officers for probable cause hearings. 
 
Strip Search Class Action Allegations 
143.  The Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs bring this 
action under Rules 23(a), 23(b)(2), and 23(b)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil 
Procedure on behalf of a class consisting of each person who, in the three years 
preceding the filing of this action, up until the date this case is terminated, was 
or will be, (a) while being held in Central Booking; (b) for presentment on either 
(c)(i)  a misdemeanor or lesser offense not involving a weapon or drugs, or (ii) a 
non-violent, non-drug related felony; and (d) strip searched without any 
  29

individualized finding of reasonable suspicion or probable cause that he was 
concealing drugs, weapons or other contraband. 
144.  Certification of a class under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2) is 
appropriate because the Defendants engage in a pattern and practice of 
conduct that has uniformly affected all members of the class, and injunctive 
relief against Defendants will benefit each and every plaintiff and class 
member. 
145.  The class is entitled to injunctive relief of terminating the above 
described custom and practice of searches not based on individualized or 
particularized suspicion or probable cause. 
146.  Certification of a class under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(3) is 
also appropriate, in that common questions of law and fact predominate over 
any individual questions, and a class action is superior for the fair and efficient 
adjudication of this controversy as detailed below.  
147.  Regarding the Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs, and 
members of the class, there are no individual questions on the issue of liability, 
because every member of the Class is subjected to the strip search practice, 
and none of the defendants has kept or keeps records of the searches and 
therefore none of the defendants can show that any of the searches were 
conducted based on an individual determination of reasonable suspicion.  
Should records exist demonstrating that such an individualized suspicion was 
used in the strip search determination, such people would, by definition, not be 
  30

members of the class. 
148.  Among the questions of law and fact common to the class are: 
    a.  whether the Defendant Wardens and Booking Center have 
and have had policies, customs, and/or practices of subjecting arrestees being 
held in Central Booking pending presentment to strip searches without an 
individualized determination that the person was in possession of drugs, 
weapons, or other contraband; 
    b.  whether such policies, customs, and/or practices, if found to 
exist, violates the Fourth Amendment; 
    c.  whether the defendants were deliberately indifferent to the 
rights of such arrestees;  
    d.  whether plaintiffs and the members of the class have 
sustained damages and, if so, the proper measure of such damages;  
    e.  whether plaintiffs and the members of the class and future 
members are entitled to equitable relief, and, if so, what is the nature of that 
relief; and 
    f.  whether determination of damages suffered by a statistically 
representative sample of the class provides the basis for determination of all 
class members’ damages except those who opt out.

  31

The exact number of class members is unknown to plaintiffs at this time, but is 
likely to consist of at least many thousands of people.

the current and past class members in its computerized booking system.

SUBSTANTIVE ALLEGATIONS 
COUNT 1 
191.  The Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs re-allege and 
incorporate by reference all allegations set forth above in this Complaint. 
192.  This Count is filed against Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski in 
their individual capacities for all purposes, and their official capacities for 
purposes of prospective injunctive relief. 
  42

193.  While being held for presentment in Central Booking on (a) 
misdemeanors not involving a weapon or drugs, or (b) non-violent, non-drug 
related felony charge(s), each of the Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named 
Plaintiffs and every other class member were subjected to a strip search 
without an individual determination that the search would reveal weapons, 
drugs or other contraband. 
194.  Subjecting an arrestee arrested on a non-drug, non-weapon 
misdemeanor, or a non-drug, non-violent felony to a strip search without an 
individual determination that the search would reveal weapons, drugs or other 
contraband violates his or her Fourth Amendment Rights. 
195.  The Defendants had actual or constructive knowledge that the 
Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs and other class members 
were being or would be subject to the strip searches and acquiesced in the 
searches. 
196.  Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski failed to supervise and train 
their staff in strip searches when the need for supervision and training was 
obvious, and remained inactive in the face of actual or constructive notice of 
the illegal searches. 
197.  Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski have each had a written 
policy that authorizes male arrestees to be automatically searched to their 
underwear, and then strip searched for whatever reason, in any manner, and 
in the presence of other arrested males, if the searching officer for any reason 
  43

suspects – reasonably or not -- that the arrested male is concealing 
contraband.   
198.  Defendants’ actions, and failure to act, as described above, directly and 
proximately and affirmatively were the moving force behind the violations of the 
Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs’ and the class members’ 
Fourth Amendment Rights. 
199.  Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski engaged in and oversaw the 
customs and practices described above, which were the moving force behind 
the deprivations to the Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs’ 
and other class members’ Fourth Amendment Rights, and the Suspicionless 
Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs and the other class members’ injuries 
resulting from the strip searches. 
200.  Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski caused the unreasonable 
strip search of the Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs and all 
other class members by deliberate indifference to the risk of constitutional 
injury by maintaining and/or acquiescing in a practice and custom of strip 
searching arrestees as described above. 
201.  Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski acted intentionally and 
unreasonably in violation of the Fourth Amendment rights of the Suspicionless 
Arrestee Strip Search Named Plaintiffs and all other class members  
202.  For all actions relating to this complaint, Defendants Franks, Murphy, 
  44

and Jednorski and other employees of Central Booking were acting within the 
scope of their employment, their acts were motivated by a desire to further the 
interests of Central Booking, the City of Baltimore, and the State of Maryland, 
and such employees were acting in furtherance of the business of Central 
Booking, the City of Baltimore, and the State of Maryland. 
203.  Defendants Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski are therefore liable under 42 
U.S.C. § 1983 for constitutional injuries to the Suspicionless Arrestee Strip 
Search Named Plaintiffs and all other class members caused by their conduct.

Booking, the City of Baltimore, and the State of Maryland. 
243.  Defendant Franks, Murphy, and Jednorski are therefore liable under 42 
U.S.C. § 1983 for constitutional injuries to the Overdetention Named Plaintiff 
and all other class members caused by their conduct.

288.  Plaintiff Eric Jones alleges and incorporates by reference all allegations

289.  This Count is an individual claim filed against Defendant Murphy in her 
individual capacity. 
290.  After his arrest, Eric Jones was unreasonably and unjustifiably held 
without presentment for at least 36 after his arrest. 
291.  Defendant Murphy, through the arrest booking system and other means 
of information, had same-time actual or constructive knowledge that Mr. Jones 
  61

had been unreasonably detained without presentment for more than 24 hours, 
and then more than 36 hours, but failed to either release each him or ensure 
that he was presented to a commissioner or other judicial officer, and instead 
continued to detain him without presentment. 
292.  Defendant Murphy, through the arrest booking system and other means 
of information, had same-time actual or constructive knowledge that Mr. Jones 
was not immediately released after the posting of his bond, and was thereafter 
not released after a superfluous commissioner’s release order was issued, and 
instead continued to detain him unnecessarily for approximately 4 or more 
additional hours. 
293.  Defendant Murphy failed to supervise and train her staff in the need for 
prompt presentments and post-bond releases when the need for supervision 
training was obvious, and remained inactive in the face of actual or 
constructive notice of the illegal detentions without presentment and after the 
posting of bond. 
294.  Defendant Murphy’s actions, and failure to act, as described above, 
directly and proximately and affirmatively were the moving force behind the 
violations of Eric Jones’ Fourth Amendment Rights. 
295.  Defendant Murphy engaged in and oversaw the customs and practices of 
chronic detentions without presentment and unreasonably delays in release 
following the posting of bond, which were the moving force behind the 
deprivation of Eric Jones’ Fourth Amendment Rights and injuries resulting 
  62

from the unreasonable and excessive detention. 
296.  Defendant Murphy caused the detention of Eric Jones by deliberate 
indifference to the risk of constitutional injury by maintaining and/or 
acquiescing in a practice and custom of detaining persons for an unreasonable 
length of time without presentment and after the posting of bond. 
297.  Defendant Murphy acted intentionally and unreasonably in violation of 
the Fourth Amendment rights Eric Jones  
298.  For all actions relating to this count, Defendant Murphy was acting 
within the scope of her employment, her acts were motivated by a desire to 
further the interests of Central Booking, the City of Baltimore, and the State of 
Maryland, and was acting in furtherance of the business of Central Booking, 
the City of Baltimore, and the State of Maryland. 
299.  Defendant Murphy is therefore liable under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for 
constitutional injuries to Eric Jones caused by the above-described conduct. 
COUNT 10 
300.  Eric Jones re-alleges and incorporates by reference all allegations set 
forth above in this Complaint. 
301.  This is an individual Count is filed against Defendants City of Baltimore 
and the Baltimore City Police Department for their policies, customs, and 
practices violating the constitutional rights of Eric Jones. 
302.  All actions by the City of Baltimore and the Baltimore City Police 
  63

Department alleged herein are pursuant to the policies, customs, and practices 
of the Baltimore City Police Department and the City of Baltimore. 
303.  The City of Baltimore and the Baltimore City Police Department 
transported Eric Jones to and placed him in the custody of Central Booking, 
with the actual or constructive knowledge that the he would face a substantial 
risk of constitutional violations set forth in Count 9. 
304.  The City of Baltimore had control over the City’s and the Baltimore City 
Police Department’s policy of transporting arrested persons to and placing 
them in the custody of Central Booking.  
305.  The City of Baltimore and the Baltimore City Police Department knew 
that Defendant Warden was deliberately indifferent to the rights of persons to 
be free from the constitutional violations set forth in Count 9. 
306.  Still, the City of Baltimore and the Baltimore City Police Department 
placed Eric Jones into the custody of Central Booking. 
307.  The City of Baltimore’s and the Baltimore City Police Department’s 
deliberate indifference to the rights of Eric Jones to be free from unreasonable 
detention without presentment, and unreasonably after the posting of bond, 
was the moving force behind his injuries.  
308.  The BPD and the City have an affirmative duty to protect arrestees from 
harm, including the risk of violations of constitutional rights by a third party to 
whom the arrestees are transferred.  The BPD and the City wholly failed to take 
  64

any affirmative act reasonably calculated to protect Eric Jones and prevent the 
unconstitutional harms alleged herein. 
309.  Defendants City of Baltimore and Baltimore City Police Department are  
therefore liable under the Fourth and the Fourteenth Amendments through 42 
U.S.C. §1983 for constitutional injuries to Eric Jones caused by their conduct 
described herein and are jointly and severally liable with all other defendants 
for injuries caused by their conduct described herein. 
IRREPARABLE INJURY AND INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
310.  Defendants are unreasonably subjecting members of each respective 
Class to strip searches, and detaining them without prompt presentment, 
which irreparably harms them, and will continue to irreparably harm them, 
even if they are later able to recover compensatory damages, thus making 
declaratory and injunctive relief necessary . 
311.  The named plaintiffs have standing to assert injunctive relief because 
they are reasonably likely to be re-admitted to Central Booking and suffer the 
same harms again. 
REQUEST FOR RELIEF 
WHEREFORE, on Counts 1 through 8, the Named Plaintiffs respectfully 
request that this Court grant the following relief: 
1)  grant a jury trial on all claims so triable;  
2)  declare that each cause of action may be maintained as a class action 
  65

pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23(b)(2) and 23(b)(3) and certify the  
following classes with the Named Plaintiffs as the Class representatives: 
a.  Suspicionless Arrestee Strip Search Class:  All persons arrested 
since May 12, 2002 on (a) misdemeanors or lesser offenses not 
involving a weapon or drugs, or (b) non-violent, non-drug related 
felony charge(s) who were subjected to strip, visual body cavity 
and/or squat searches without any individualized finding of 
reasonable suspicion that they were concealing drugs, weapons or 
other contraband, by employees of Central Booking, while they 
were held in Central Booking waiting for presentment before a 
commissioner or other judicial officer.  
b.  Non-Private Strip Search Class:  All persons who since May 12, 
2002 were subjected to strip searches by employees of Central 
Booking in the presence of other arrested persons while they were 
held in Central Booking waiting for presentment before a 
commissioner or other judicial officer. 
c.  Equal Protection Strip Search Class:  All persons who are male 
arrestees arrested on all types of charges since May 12, 2002, 
including drug and violent offenses, who were subjected to strip, 
visual body cavity and/or squat searches, by employees of Central 
Booking, while they were held in Central Booking waiting for 
presentment before a commissioner or other judicial officer. 
  66

d.  Overdetention Class:  All persons who have been arrested since 
May 12, 2002 and were detained at Central Booking for more than 
48 hours without presentment. 
3)  appoint the named plaintiffs as the representative plaintiffs; 
4)  appoint Sean Day, Barrett Litt and William Claiborne as class counsel; 
5)  declare that defendants’ acts alleged above violate the Fourth and 
Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution by illegally strip searching 
plaintiffs as alleged herein; 
6)  declare that the defendants’ acts alleged above violate the Fourth and 
Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution by detaining arrested persons 
more than 48 hours without presentment;  
7)  preliminarily and permanently enjoin defendants from pursuing the 
course of conduct complained of herein; 
8)  award all plaintiffs compensatory and consequential damages in an 
amount to be determined and reduce the award to judgment; 
9)  award plaintiffs attorneys' fees and costs incurred in bringing this action 
by awarding them a third of the common fund generated by the class and 
expenses or under 42 U.S.C. § 1988 and any other applicable statute;  
10)  grant such other relief as this Court deems just and proper. 
AND WHEREFORE, on Counts 9 and 10, Plaintiff Eric Jones request judgment 
  67

against Defendants Murphy, the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore, and the 
Baltimore City Police Department, jointly and severally, for reasonable 
compensatory damages including pain and suffering to be determined at trial, 
attorney’s fees and costs, and post-judgment interest, and such other and 
further relief as the nature of this cause requires. 
Respectfully submitted,

documents.title: Memorandum
documents.text:
Case 1:05-cv-01287-CCB   Document 265   Filed 02/23/09   Page 1 of 3
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF MARYLAND
:
ERIC JONES, et al.  :
:
:
v. :      Civil No. CCB-05-1287
:
SUSAN MURPHY, et al.  :
:
...o0o...
MEMORANDUM
At the request of the state defendants in the § 1983 litigation, I referred to Magistrate Judge
Susan K. Gauvey for resolution a discovery dispute set forth in the defendants’ motion for protective
order filed March 18, 2008.  The dispute involves three memoranda written in 2000, 2002, and 2005
by Assistant Attorneys General to the then-Commissioners of the state’s Division of Pretrial
Detention and Services (the “Division”) concerning arrestee search practices at Baltimore Central
Booking and Intake Center (“BCBIC”).  By letter memorandum issued November 26, 2008, after
hearing argument and receiving supplemental briefing, Judge Gauvey found that the defendants had
failed to establish the documents were protected by either the attorney-client privilege or by the
executive “deliberative process” privilege.  Accordingly, she ordered the memoranda be produced
to plaintiffs in this case.  The defendants filed objections and requested a stay of the order to
produce, which I granted.  After reviewing the documents ex parte and in camera, I heard oral
argument on February 18, 2009.  For the reasons that follow, I will affirm Judge Gauvey’s ruling.
A magistrate judge’s ruling on a discovery matter may be modified or set aside only if the
party objecting has shown the ruling to be “clearly erroneous or contrary to law.”  Fed. R. Civ. P.
72(a);  see also 28 U.S.C. § 636(b)(1)(A).  Based on the record before her, Judge Gauvey’s ruling
1

Case 1:05-cv-01287-CCB   Document 265   Filed 02/23/09   Page 2 of 3
was neither clearly erroneous as to the relevant facts nor contrary to controlling law.
In brief summary, and as defendants essentially concede, Judge Gauvey correctly held that
the attorney-client privilege may protect a communication from the attorney to the client but only
insofar as that communication reveals confidential information obtained from the client. United
States v. (Under Seal), 748 F.2d 871, 874 (4th Cir. 1984).  The burden is on the defendants to
identify the confidential client information contained in the memoranda, and the two affidavits of
Deputy Commissioner Benjamin Brown fail to do so.  Significantly, no affidavits were provided by
any author or recipient of any of the memoranda other than Deputy Commissioner Brown, who is
copied on the 2005 memorandum.  Similarly, the burden is on the party seeking to establish the
executive or deliberative process privilege to establish its applicability, see Hanson v. U.S. Agency
for Int’l Dev., 372 F.3d 286, 290 (4th Cir. 2004) (FOIA litigaton), and the Brown affidavits are not
sufficient to do so, nor is it self-evident from the contents of the memoranda that they are truly
predecisional and part of the “give-and-take” process the privilege protects. City of Va. Beach, Va.
v. U.S. Dep’t of Commerce, 995 F.2d 1247, 1253 (4th Cir. 1993).
The defendants in their objections also rely on the attorney work-product doctrine, which
was not addressed by Judge Gauvey.1  Once again, the Brown affidavits simply are not sufficient
to establish, as Fourth Circuit law requires, that the documents were prepared “because of”
anticipated litigation and in preparation for that litigation.  National Union Fire Ins. Co. v. Murray
Sheet Metal Co., 967 F.2d 980, 984 (4th Cir. 1992); see also Hanson, 372 F.3d at 292-93.  While
the documents refer to certain litigation, it is again not evident that they were drafted because of that
1 This omission is understandable given the defendants’ failure to argue the point other
than by way of footnote in their reply memorandum.  (See Defs.’ Reply at 4 n.2.)
2

Case 1:05-cv-01287-CCB   Document 265   Filed 02/23/09   Page 3 of 3
litigation, as opposed to providing general legal advice, including non-confidential information
about litigation.  Accordingly, there is insufficient support in the record before Judge Gauvey or the
objections before me to establish that the attorney work-product doctrine bars disclosure of these
documents.
To be clear, this ruling is limited, as it must be, to the specific facts and documents before
the court.  It should not be taken to mean that the state defendants could not establish and rely on
the deliberative process or attorney-client privilege, or benefit from work-product protection, as they
conduct litigation in the future.  The court recognizes the importance of those protections, when
properly established, in the conduct of the state’s business.  For the reasons stated above, however,
Judge Gauvey’s thorough and carefully considered ruling in this case will be affirmed.
A separate Order follows.
      February 23, 2009                                /s/                           
Date Catherine C. Blake
United States District Judge
3
